parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several approaches show evidence for mitigating environmental pollution from salmon farming.
[Statement 2]: Fallowing periods demonstrate effectiveness in mitigating pollution from salmon farming.
[Statement 3]: A trial in Tasmania found that sediment community structure under Atlantic salmon cages became more similar to non-impacted sites over two fallowing cycles.
[Statement 4]: Three studies on leaving fallow periods during fish farming found that after fallowing, invertebrate community composition became similar to the composition before fish were added.
[Statement 5]: After fallowing periods in fish farming, the abundances of pollution-indicator polychaete worms decreased.
[Statement 6]: Following fallowing periods, invertebrate communities at fish farms remained different from communities at sites without fish farms.
[Statement 7]: Integrated aquaculture systems show promise for waste management.
[Statement 8]: A study in Canada found that blue mussels absorbed waste from a salmon farm.
[Statement 9]: Studies in the USA and Scotland reported enhanced growth of scallops when placed adjacent to fish farms.
[Statement 10]: Studies in the USA and Scotland reported enhanced algal growth when algae were placed adjacent to fish farms.
[Statement 11]: Natural control methods for reducing chemical treatments include using cleaner wrasse for sea lice control.
[Statement 12]: One controlled study in Ireland found corkwing and goldskinny cleaner wrasse were as effective at controlling lice infestation as chemical treatments.
[Statement 13]: Lighting modifications show potential for mitigating issues in salmon farming.
[Statement 14]: A study in Norway reported lower numbers of lice on salmon kept in low intensity artificial light or natural lighting.
[Statement 15]: Non-chemical treatments like freshwater bathing provide mixed results for disease control.
[Statement 16]: Studies in Australia showed mixed evidence for freshwater bathing reducing amoebic gill disease.
[Statement 17]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of improving fish food to reduce waste production.
[Statement 18]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of locating aquaculture systems in vegetated areas.
[Statement 19]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of cleaning waste water before environmental release.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several husbandry practices beyond feed and chemical treatments can improve fish health on Atlantic salmon farms.
[Statement 2]: Fallowing systems can reduce parasites and disease.
[Statement 3]: A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using fallowing.
[Statement 4]: Fallowing also helps reduce pollution.
[Statement 5]: A trial in Tasmania found sediment community structure under Atlantic salmon cages became more similar to non-impacted sites over two fallowing cycles.
[Statement 6]: Vaccination programs show effectiveness.
[Statement 7]: Controlled studies from Iceland and Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated control groups when exposed to disease-causing bacteria.
[Statement 8]: Infrastructure maintenance is important.
[Statement 9]: Replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbor seal predation.
[Statement 10]: Selective breeding for disease resistance traits can improve health outcomes.
[Statement 11]: A study in Norway found increased survival levels in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis when the salmon's family was bred for high resistance compared to low resistance.
[Statement 12]: The use of probiotics and immunostimulants also shows promise.
[Statement 13]: A study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed probiotics before exposure to disease-causing bacteria.
[Statement 14]: A Norwegian study showed reduced lice infections when salmon were fed diets with beta-glucans.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several non-pesticide interventions show effectiveness for controlling sea lice on farmed salmon.
[Statement 2]: Cleaner wrasse, which are natural control agents, show mixed effectiveness in controlling sea lice.
[Statement 3]: A controlled study in Ireland found that corkwing and goldskinny cleaner wrasse were as effective at controlling lice infestation as chemical treatments.
[Statement 4]: The same Irish study found that rockcook cleaner wrasse were ineffective at preventing lice outbreaks.
[Statement 5]: Lighting alteration appears to be a consistently effective method for controlling sea lice on farmed salmon.
[Statement 6]: A study in Norway reported lower numbers of lice on salmon kept in low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting.
[Statement 7]: The Norwegian study found that higher intensity artificial light correlated with higher lice numbers on salmon.
[Statement 8]: Dietary interventions show promise for controlling sea lice on farmed salmon.
[Statement 9]: A study in Norway found that salmon fed a diet of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein had 28% reduced lice infection levels.
[Statement 10]: Adding beta-glucans to the salmon diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% compared with controls.
[Statement 11]: Fallowing systems demonstrate effectiveness in controlling sea lice on farmed salmon.
[Statement 12]: A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages that used a fallowing system.
[Statement 13]: Probiotics show potential as a non-pesticide intervention for farmed salmon.
[Statement 14]: One replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to disease-causing bacteria.

_claude-sonnet-4__Besides fallowing, what other methods can mitigate the impact of salmon farms on the surrounding benthic environment and local species?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several potential methods to mitigate salmon farming impacts on benthic environments have been identified.
[Statement 2]: Most potential methods to mitigate salmon farming impacts on benthic environments lack direct scientific evaluation.
[Statement 3]: Mooring aquaculture cages so the cages move in response to changing current direction is a potential method to mitigate salmon farming impacts.
[Statement 4]: Locating aquaculture systems in vegetated areas is a potential method to mitigate salmon farming impacts.
[Statement 5]: Reducing aquaculture stocking densities is a potential method to mitigate salmon farming impacts.
[Statement 6]: Improving fish food and pellets to reduce aquaculture waste production is a potential method to mitigate salmon farming impacts.
[Statement 7]: Introducing and enforcing water quality regulations for aquaculture systems is a potential method to mitigate salmon farming impacts.
[Statement 8]: Using species from more than one level of a food web in aquaculture systems is a potential method to mitigate salmon farming impacts.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of these interventions on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations.
[Statement 10]: The only action with supporting evidence for mitigating salmon farming impacts was ceasing or prohibiting aquaculture activity.
[Statement 11]: Two Mediterranean Sea studies found that after ceasing aquaculture activity, invertebrate community composition remained different from unfarmed sites.
[Statement 12]: After aquaculture activity was ceased, overall invertebrate abundance became similar to unfarmed sites.
[Statement 13]: After aquaculture activity was ceased, the abundance of health-indicating worms increased.
[Statement 14]: After aquaculture activity was ceased, the abundance of pollution-indicating worms decreased.

[Statement 12]: Breeding for resistance traits can help develop salmon lines with increased resistance to parasites.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the available strategies for reducing the environmental impact of waste from salmon farms on the surrounding ecosystem?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several strategies are available for reducing the environmental impact of waste from salmon farms on surrounding ecosystems.
[Statement 2]: Fallowing is a proven approach where the sediment community structure under Atlantic salmon cages became more similar to non-impacted sites over two fallowing cycles.
[Statement 3]: A fallow period during fish farming shows that the invertebrate community composition becomes similar to the composition that occurred before fish were added.
[Statement 4]: During a fallow period in fish farming, the abundances of pollution-indicator polychaete worms decrease.
[Statement 5]: After a fallow period, invertebrate communities at fish farm sites remain different from communities at sites without fish farms.
[Statement 6]: Integrated aquaculture systems offer biological waste utilization.
[Statement 7]: In an integrated system, blue mussels absorbed waste from a salmon farm.
[Statement 8]: Enhanced algal growth occurred when algae were placed adjacent to fish farms.
[Statement 9]: One study found no evidence that oysters and mussels were feeding on fish farm waste.
[Statement 10]: Greater growth of scallops was reported when the scallops were grown next to fish farms.
[Statement 11]: Improving fish food and pellets to reduce aquaculture waste production is a strategy that lacks research evidence.
[Statement 12]: Locating aquaculture systems in areas with fast currents is a strategy that lacks research evidence.
[Statement 13]: Using other bioremediation methods in aquaculture is a strategy that lacks research evidence.
[Statement 14]: Mooring aquaculture cages so the cages move in response to changing current direction is a strategy that lacks research evidence.
[Statement 15]: Co-locating aquaculture systems with other activities to maximize marine space use is a strategy that lacks research evidence.

[Statement 1]: Based on available evidence from studies in Canada, there is limited specific research documented on alternative feed ingredients for aquaculture.

[Statement 3]: Two replicated studies from Canada and Scotland found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both plant-based and fish meal diet types.
[Statement 4]: Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
[Statement 5]: Regarding waste management techniques in Canadian aquaculture, there is evidence of integrated aquaculture systems being studied.
[Statement 6]: A study in Canada found that blue mussels absorbed waste from a salmon farm.
